everybody how's it going my name is Matt Bartos and I am a PhD candidate at the
University of Michigan where I study civil engineering and my research focuses on the next generation of smart
water systems so what's a smart water system essentially it's a system that
uses real-time monitoring and control to improve the quality of service to cut
operation maintenance and construction costs and also to prevent potential environmental and human health impacts
such as combined sewer overflows toxic algal blooms and fatalities due to
flooding so a major focus of my research is a large scare a large scale wireless
sensor network for real-time flood monitoring in the dallas-fort Worth Metroplex and you can see a couple
pictures of our sensor network we deployed roughly 40 sirs within the dallas-fort Worth Metroplex and the goal is to monitor
River stage so the water depth at the level of individual roadways and in
doing so we hope to send targeted alerts to motorists to prevent them from
driving into flooded roadways to achieve better routing of emergency services basically to ensure that we are not
sending ambulances or other responders into dangerous areas and perhaps someday
as connected and autonomous vehicles become more common we'd actually like to
be able to route traffic and real time around flooded roadways to avoid potential fatalities and this is a
really serious problem because in the United States roughly seventy four percent of flood related fatalities are
vehicle related they occur when people get stuck in crossings and they can't
get out because well because there's flooding so so so we built these
wireless sensor networks we built the cloud back-end using AWS using all the technologies we talked about at these
sessions today and surprisingly the biggest challenge for us hasn't been the firmware or the hardware or the cloud
back-end or any of that stuff it's ensuring that the data that we're providing to our stakeholders to the
people from the municipalities from flood control districts is both timely and reliable this is not an easy problem
to solve so timely in the sense that if the data arrives too late it's not going to be of
much use to emergency management it's not going to be a much used to providing alerts at the same time the data needs
to be reliable so essentially not too many false positives or false negatives if you have if you don't detect a flood
event that's a major problem and if you detect too many false positive bits out that's also a problem because people
will no longer trust your data so and to address these problems we use this ISA
blab to develop a sorry yeah we use this
ISA blab to develop a framework for real-time quality control and quality
assurance of sensor data it's essential a specification for describing
operations to quality control your data
and these specific this specification takes the form of quality control
recipes which are documents that are specified in a json-ld format that we describe in our project that it performs
atomic transformations on your data these transformations are designed to be
one human readable so that you don't need to understand a programming language to understand what operations
are being applied to the data second their version Abul so you can upload them to a repository and know the exact
history of what's happened at the site this is a major issue because when you're working with real sensor data
there's a lot of strange things that you wouldn't necessarily think happened like for instance like a tree might fall in
front of your sensor or your maintenance crew may move the sensor introducing a bias into the rest of your measurements
and you need a you need a format for accounting for all of the strange things that might happen it's not going to be
taken care of by a one-size-fits-all algorithm finally we want the all of the steps to be reproducible and to describe
the history of the sensor for improved data provenance down the road so here I have a cup just a couple of examples of
these recipes these are just tiny screenshots of much larger documents but on the top there and the top panel you

the same site they're measuring a water level over a bridge on a relatively
